article_title: New law to help lactating mothers
article_text:
New law to help lactating mothers

Photo: Tom Reel / San Antonio Express-News The Texas Breastfeeding Coalition visits the Texas Senate on March...

In a move advocates say is a win for infant health, public employers in Texas must accommodate all lactating employees by providing private spaces and adequate breaks to express their breast milk.

article_metadata.description: In a move advocates say is a win for infant health, public employers in Texas must accommodate all lactating employees by providing private spaces and adequate breaks to express their breast milk.  Federal breastfeeding rules, which were included as part of the Affordable Care Act, don’t cover salaried workers, and the bill in Texas was an effort to close at least part of that loophole, said Alice Bufkin, early opportunities policy associate at Texans Care for Children, a nonprofit group focused on improving state policies for children.  The academy points to such health benefits as protection against respiratory illnesses, ear infections, gastrointestinal diseases and allergies, including asthma.  Breast-fed babies also have a lower risk of sudden infant death syndrome and less risk for adolescent and adult obesity.  The new state law doesn’t seem to be causing much disruption because public employers already have made accommodations for lactating employees under the Affordable Care Act.
article_metadata.author.name: By L.M. Sixel, Houston Chronicle
